f6_assessments.q0: This solution works in two ways. There the online transaction that enables the user to pay in ADA and the vendor to be paid in ADA, and there is also a way for affiliates to get paid in ADA. This creates opportunity to a lot of exchange transactions. More transactions means a stronger blockchain, coming to the benefit of the entire community.

f6_assessments.q2: All variables are present in the proposal in terms of auditability, but more information on the executing team is needed to determine this aspect of both feasibility and auditability.

f6_assessments.q0: This project meets the expectations and challenges set in the fund and if selected and completed would have a large impact in opening doors for Cardano to larger populations through their proposed solution.

f6_assessments.q1: They provided website but I can't find any evidence of their skills and experience. They mention in the roadmap, that they still need to acquire developers for some parts. It would be a risk to leave that to the last minute and can slow down the building process. Having the necessary team already in place enables you to get a head start and you will be able to construct a solid plan as all the key members can contribute to the planning. They go into great detail explaining how existing products work, but fail to clearly explain how their product will be built from a technical perspective. You need to show the reader how you will go about building this. The time to complete this seems reasonable. They consider the challenge of adoption, but don't mention how they will address it. Budget is broken down, although I think they could have broken down the development part as well. It would be great to see how much you spend  on the different parts of development.
f6_assessments.q2: The roadmap and KPIs seem trackable and achievable. For the roadmap it would be better to state what you are building at what time instead of just saying code development and test. f6_assessments.q0: The proposal describes a complete plan on how to build a plug-in to address the problem of the challenge, but it does not go deep enough into explaining how this plug-in will be built in order to overcome the main problems raised. It states what is desired in the final solution, but it does not say more precisely what features the solution will have in order to deliver what is being promised. The metrics described are aligned with the objectives desired, but the proposal does not focus on the value the team will be bringing to the ecosystem. How it will make the experience smooth for the customer, how the team will guarantee the solution is scalable enough to serves millions of customers and several merchants at the same time and how the final product will have the desired quality remains a mystery.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal does not provide enough information about the background of the team. This way it is hard to assess if they have enough skills and experience to conduct this project. Even though the budget could have been better explained it is broken down into identifiable items and all in all has a reasonable sum to address the challenge. The timetable is reasonable as well but could have been better explained at each stage. In other words, what is being done and what is achieved at each stage could have been more deeply explored. Finally, no thoughts were giving regarding the case of the team needing additional funds.
f6_assessments.q2: I would not say there is enough information to audit the progress of the proposal. The KPIs defined are on the right track but they could have been more objective and more measurable. The roadmap is well structured, but the milestones lack a more prolix description. Finally, what is defined as success is not easily measured. So even if the project is concluded in total, it will be hard to assess how well it did because it was not clearly established what was expected at the beginning.

f6_assessments.q0:
The problem statement addresses the challenge settings very well and provides a good clear to understand solution to the problem. 

The challenge settings ask for ways to integrate AdaPay solution via plugin to various ecommerce platforms. The proposal here gives a well detailed description what their solution will be targeting, unlike many other proposals, this proposal has focussed on identification of the existing problem sets when it comes to crypto adoption for subsectors within ecommerce domain. 

As we are aware that whole blockchain space is shaking up the traditional financial systems such as banking which are not fit for a fast changing digital world, it makes sense to also tap into the different sectors with in the ecommerce space. This proposal here not only fulfills the challenge settings but also gives a good description to the community on how an integration of AdaPay solution plugin will disrupt/improve the ecommerce space. 

Therefore, full points from my side.
f6_assessments.q1:
I will give my take in two parts starting with the good -- the plan

1. The plan presented here is quite elaborative. The week wise distribution of implementation plan is clear to understand. The success definition (minimal clicks to checkout, easy UX, mass adoption) is in align with success settings of the challenge.  

The budget break down is fairly written and well distributed, although i see some room of improvements there. E.g. How they calculated 20k $ based on hours ? what rates they are expecting for developers? would have been nice to have this information.

The experience

2. This is where i see the proposal is a little bit lacking transparency. Although they have provided good links (to their website) and also to some snapshots as attachments where one can see some work has been done with respect to checkout integration with BTC etc. Nevertheless, for me would be better if there was more clarity on atleast the lead engineer credentials.  This gives more confidence to the community as in who will be the face of this proposal. 

I like that tech stack is clear, and it is also clear what kind of developers the team will need, however, it is also written they will acquire developers in week 1 and 2. So i see some risks there, but since tech stack (react/nodejs) is quite in demand, i assume that finding these developers in a country like India should not be a big problem. Overall, i see some room for improvement hence taking away one star.
f6_assessments.q2:
I think the proposal has given good information on different stages of implementation of this proposal. Therefore, i think it would be very easy for community to closely monitor progress and eventually successful completion of this project.

The weekwise plan, and what community can expect in terms of challenges are outlined. This allows community to be also aware of any risks associated with project progress. 

We can see that different set of ideas are presented for a future way forward, leading the community to believe that proposer has thought through the long term impact/possibilities of this proposal. This is always a positive sign, when it comes to having a close feedback loop.

Therefore full points from my side. A very well written proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: First off, this particular proposal is part of an elegant, ambitious project that has 7 proposals spanning throughout Fund7.  It can be difficult to consider a proposal of this nature, in isolation, without understanding how it connects to the larger picture, however, I do believe each of these proposals must stand ultimately on their own merits.  So lets consider this proposal in the COTI challenge.  It does meet the requirements of the challenge brief, as it proposes to develop an AdaPay plugin, specifically targeting Shopify, but the proposers indicate numerous other popular platforms like WooCommerce that should fall within its scope as well.  To this end they expect to develop the plugin and deploy it on their existing ecommerce enabled site for testing, and then rolling out the finished product for mass adoption.  Their focus on and prioritization of user experience, married to an insistence on simplicity indicates that the end result should be exactly what COTI is expecting.
f6_assessments.q1: At first blush, a successful launch and delivery seems likely for this proposal.  The roadmap is well laid out, and a surplus of resources are being requested for a full stack development team, presumably freelance (for a plugin, this is adequate; for the overall Konma project at large you would like to see this development team in-house and dedicated).  For the overall layout of the Konma projects, it is clear there is some kind of management team behind the inspiration, but (and in the true spirit of a DAO) I could not find any information on them.  And while the roadmap appears detailed, when you realize it spans 6 months of development for this plugin, suddenly it seems to lack both granularity and perspective.  18 weeks to testnet will likely have this piece of software substantially behind its peers.  Is this a UI/UX issue?  If so I think voters would like an idea about how the interface would handle, in the name of 'good things come to those who wait.'  Alternatively, more granularity in the roadmap, suggesting specific points at which development is achieving some of COTI's KPIs, such as platform compatibility, would be a welcome nuance.  The proposer does demonstrate good knowledge of resources required for delivery, listing a complete team, including compliance officer.
f6_assessments.q2: The roadmap laid out by this proposal has a bi-weekly flow, but the auditability of these bi-weekly demarcations is not clear.  The bi-weekly descriptions are quite general -continue code development and test- and lack specifically auditable milestones, such as commits.  The KPI only generally matches COTIs campaign brief:  a plugin will be developed and launched, an increase in adoption is expected.  It would help to know what the significance of the initial userbase is, the Konma marketplace, but this is one of the difficulties of assessing this one piece of a broader funding approach in Catalyst.  The viability of this marketplace may be tied to other proposals.  There isn't any real information about whether the indicated KPIs of adoption and transactions are during testing or are the targets of the eventual ecommerce rollout.  And even at that, they lack the specificity to be actionable.  The long development cycle combined with the lack of specificity leaves doubt that this project can stay on track, especially when one considers that this team is spread throughout 7 total proposals in Fund7.
